Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2+ months. I interviewed at VMware in August 2014.
Interview Description: Very bad experience with VMware. I took the phone interview on Aug. They gave me an onsite on Sep. 18th. 10 days before the onsite, they send me an email and told me they have to remove me from the onsite since they realize I am a new graduate student. I have to cancle my ticked and reschedule all my other interview
Interview Questions: NAN

Application: I applied through a recruiter. I interviewed at VMware in September 2014.
Interview Description: 30 min phone screen and a 4.5 hour full loop interview; mostly technical coding questions and some SOAR stories; The first 3 rounds were full coding and with hiring manager it was mostly explaining projects and design questions.
Interview Questions: Design a smart pointer class   1 Answer

Application: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at VMware in October 2014.
Interview Description: It is a On campus interview. At first I take the online quiz on the Hackerrank.com. Then they managed a interview in the campus. The interviewer can not write code, only ask me a puzzle. And then ask me about the resume. The whole interview last about 30 minutes. And a week later, I get the result.
Interview Questions: Given 25 horses, and 5 tracks. Only at most 5 horses can be in one round's match. Ask at least how many rounds to get the three most fast horses.   5 Answers

Application: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware in October 2014.
Interview Description: I had two back-to-back interviews with VMware on my college campus.The first interview was with a hiring manager. It was non-technical and lasted 45 minutes. It primarily consisted of a brain-teaser question unrelated to software. This interviewer was professional and informative.The second interview was easily the worst I've ever had. The interviewer was arrogant, impatient (to the point of interrupting me to ask the next question), and made it clear within the first 10 seconds that he had no interest in interviewing me. The first question he asked was a brain-teaser unrelated to software. The second question he asked was an algorithm question. This interview lasted about 45 minutes, and I fully regret not walking out after the first 5.Based on this experience I would never consider working for VMware.
Interview Questions: NAN

Application: I applied through college or university. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at VMware.
Interview Description: The process was essentially painless. I met the recruiter at a career fair, and we arranged an interview on the spot. The interviewer was running a few minutes late, but ultimately was polite and knowledgeable. The interview itself was very easy for the role I was looking at – iOS developer. At the end, though, I expressed my reluctance to work in Atlanta, AirWatch's only location, which I believe resulted in the company not wanting to take the process any further.
Interview Questions: None of the questions were challenging. The most difficult, though, was, "describe the functioning of APNS," Apple's push notification system.   Answer Question

Application: I applied through college or university. The process took 4+ weeks. I interviewed at VMware in October 2014.
Interview Description: Apply on career fair, got an on campus interview. 1 hour long. Questions are easy, basic data structure coding on white paper. Also some operating system question , mainly definition~
Interview Questions: NAN

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2+ months. I interviewed at VMware (Cambridge, MA) in March 2014.
Interview Description: I received an email from a recruiter via Linked In regarding an "invite only" recruiting event to take place in Cambridge, MA. The event was to be held roughly 2 months from when I received the initial communication. I was told that VMWare was looking to fill several engineering roles "up and down the stack", and that they were looking for "every background" and "all experience levels".After expressing my interest, I was instructed to take a 1 hour coding challenge via Interview Street (now Hacker Rank). The challenge was a single problem that covered basic data structures/algorithms and could be completed in the language of my choice.After completing the coding challenge with 100% accuracy, I was invited to attend the event, and VMWare connected me with the appropriate people to arrange travel, ask questions, etc. So far so good.2 days before I was scheduled to attend the event, I received a call that my interview would be cancelled. The hiring managers were looking for a very specific skill set, which I did not have. While all the communication I had received up until this point stressed that VMWare was looking to fill multiple different roles, and was looking for "solid CS fundamentals" and the ability to "quickly ramp up and learn new technologies", it seems the hiring managers were looking specifically for kernel developers with extensive experience in C.I was very surprised to see that such a communication gap had occurred between the hiring team(s) and the recruiting team. I felt that this should have been caught much, much sooner. I had been in contact with VMWare for nearly 2 months! During this time I received very detailed documentation describing the general skills that they were looking for. That being said, I did appreciate them stopping the process as soon as it became clear there was not a match.
Interview Questions: Unfortunately, none.   Answer Question

Application: I applied online. The process took 4 days. I interviewed at VMware (San Francisco, CA) in October 2013.
Interview Description: I was called by the HR. And the HR was asking personal questions in very diplomatic way, trying to get to know if I was married! It sounded very weird. Later had an technical interview and the interviewer didn't acknowledge whatever I was explaining, and mentioned I will be contacted within 4-5 days. Never got a call back. Emailed HR to follow up and never received any reply. Apparently the HR now is with drop box!Tech question: few complex recursive problems and asked the output and complexity.
Interview Questions: Do you have a family?   1 Answer

Application: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at VMware (Atlanta, GA) in February 2014.
Interview Description: I started out interviewing on my college campus and thought I did ok. I was then invited to an on-campus interview and interviewed with two different people and thought they both went pretty well.
Interview Questions: The questions where pretty easy compared to other interviews I had. Fibonacci sequence ( I did O(n) version),find the intersection of two lists, get all the leaf nodes of a binary tree. What is restful protocol.   Answer Question

Application: I applied online. The process took 6+ weeks. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA) in May 2014.
Interview Description: There were two phone interviews and a face to face interview with the hiring manager. The first phone interview was with a recruiter who basically checked boxes to ensure that I met basic qualifications. The second phone interview was with the hiring manager. Questions were a mix of situational and technical. The third interview was face to face. More situational questions than technical questions. There were also some general problem solving questions.
Interview Questions: How do you work with a superior that requires you to commit to unrealistic or unobtainable goals?   Answer Question

Application: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at VMware.
Interview Description: I got referal from employee and got response after 2 weeks. They arranged a 45 mins phone interview. The interviewer was quite nice. I didn't manage to write the complete solution to the coding question but he let me send the code within 30 minutes, it could just for formality though.
Interview Questions: Not so many difficult questions. At first some OS questions about thread/process, deadlocks, followed by a coding question that find the next smallest node in a BST then the given number. I was not well prepared though.   Answer Question

Application: I applied through an employee referral. The process took a week. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA) in June 2013.
Interview Description: Applied for VMFS engineering team. Recruiter contacted online. Scheduled onsite interview. Total 6 face to face interviews including 1 with engineer in Bangalore. Lost some time in setting video conferencing with engineer in Bangalore. Asked questions about filesystem work, whiteboard coding questions, algorithms, system programming. All interviewers were helpful. Used to take picture of whiteboard at the end of interview.
Interview Questions: Design and implement recursive mutex   Answer Question

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA) in April 2013.
Interview Description: I have been talking with these people for a while, even before graduating. Once I am graduating, they were fast to follow up (in fact, they are the fastest to do so). However they were not pushy or anything, which cannot be said about all the employers/HR out there.The exact interview is quite fun, with interview questions being interleaved with chats about your work, their work and their short-term to mid-term focus. This gives you an idea of what you will get to work on and helps to have an informed decision. Again, many companies from my experience does not provide such information which makes a decision hard.As for interview questions, expect some of the typical coding questions with some system design questions. The latter is probably due to my area of expertise. Be prepared. There is really nothing special about coding questions. Study for it.
Interview Questions: The employer has asked that I kept the question to myself, and I would respect that.   Answer Question

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took a week. I interviewed at VMware (Seattle, WA) in October 2013.
Interview Description: I was contacted on LinkedIn by a recruiter about a private interview event in my city. The communication was pleasant and informative. I was asked to complete a timed (one hour) coding question online at my convenience. If the coding question went well, then I would be invited to participate at the interview event. I completed the coding question, and submitted my solution. A few days later I received word that they would be not be moving forward with me.
Interview Questions: You are given a dictionary, such as /usr/share/dict/words, containing a list of words, one per line. You are also given seven tiles. Each tile is either blank or contains a single lowercase letter (a-z).List all of the words from the dictionary that can be produced by using some or all of the seven tiles, in any order. A blank tile is a wildcard, and can be used in place of any letter.Try to use a minimal amount of memory.1. Find all of the words that can be formed if you don't have to deal with blank tiles. (You may skip this step and go straight to step 2).2. Find all of the words that can be formed, including those where blank tiles are used as wildcards.3. Would you do things differently if you had to process several hundred tile sets with the same dictionary?   5 Answers

Application: The process took 2+ weeks. I interviewed at VMware in February 2007.
Interview Description: The recruiter had a formal chat and then arranged 3 1:1 interview over phone. Even though all the interviews are fared well, there is no response from them. I sent a mail to one of the interviewers and he mentioned that the Manager is out of station and will give a call once she is back. But no response anymore.
Interview Questions: How do you do compression? Which is better whether inline or background? If so what are the advantages and disadvantages   Answer Question

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware (San Francisco, CA) in January 2007.
Interview Description: At the time I had my resume posted online; I was approached by VmWare and requested to interview with them by phone.I agreed to take the interview and was informed that the interview would be related to C++ questions.When the interview started, I was initially slightly taken aback at the brusque manner in which the interview proceeded; not unfriendly per-se, but there was hardly any preamble before the interviewer launched into his series of questions. I wasn't terribly put off by the manner, really; this was a screening interview, after all... however, as an experienced engineer with a steady capability to land the job I want, I now view interview processes as a 2-way street and expect the opportunity to ask at least a couple of questions.The real issue I had with the interview was the content. Out of about 10 questions, not one related to C++, which was what I had been told; I don't care if an employer wants to keep the content of their interview secret, but to advise me of the content in advance, but then switch tack without warning is bad coordination at best, and sneaky at worst.The actual questions asked were complex algorithm problems, not generic problem solvers, but very specific algorithmic-related scenarios, for which you pull a known algorighm out of the box and recite it; essentially a memory-test.It became a bit ridiculous when the interviewer indicated that if I already knew the answer that I should tell him this and he would go to the next question.... So I was expected to, within seconds, over a phone, solve fairly complex problems that would normally take at least a couple of hours to review and solve from first principles.It was basically a catch-22 situation; If I happened to know the answer , I wasn't supposed to give it, but if I didn't know the answer I was supposed to, at the drop of a hat, come up with the full solution.It's a fairly standard process to present oblique problems to interviewees and see how they grapple with them; I do this myself when I am on the other side of the desk, but in a phone interview you simply don't have the time to work through hyper-complex problems that have specifically only one answer, and it is impossible for the interviewer to determine your collaborative capabailities; it becomes, essentially, a stress-test.Anyways, in the end I muddled through the problems; for the algorithms I didn't know I did pretty well, I think. In fact I pulled some decent solutions out on short notice. I didn't care if they called back, I wasn't going to accept any job there; I knew I would end up working with the interviewer and, to be frank, I don't work well with people who are inflexible in their thinking. They did call back about a year later indicating that they were interested in talking to me again. At this point I had landed a great position at a different company and was still a bit annoyed so I declined.In conclusion, for this particular group, and perhaps only this person in question, it appeared that they were filtering out people who didn't have robot-savant type quailities. This might not reflect the culture as whole, but it certainly turned me off this place.The lack of a follow-up email after the interview was not very kosher, either... I didn't hear from them again until they were on a different recruiting drive.
Interview Questions: "I'm going to ask you a series of questions, if you know the textbook answer, don't bother answering and let me know and I'll just move on to the next one, OK?"   2 Answers

Application: The process took 5 days. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA) in January 2008.
Interview Description: They turned me down. Interviewers were highly condescending, and looking for specific answers. After they declined me, I got offers from Microsoft and Google, with a good salary / stock combo at each.They should learn to treat interviewees with respect, and train their interviewers to judge better.Based on interviewer's attitude, I wouldnt wanna work there anyways, even if they offered me a better salary.
Interview Questions: dont remember. some programming puzzle.   1 Answer

Application: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA) in January 2011.
Interview Description: Initial communication consisted of discussions with a recruiter followed by a phone screen with the hiring manger. Interview was all-day at the VMware campus in Palo Alto. It consisted of one-on-one meetings with a number of engineers of various ranks from within the group, as well as the hiring manager and another group manager. The interviews focused on programming questions, but there were also systems design questions. Recruiter followed up in a couple of days following meeting with the interview team.
Interview Questions: How would you implement VMotion?   Answer Question

Application: The process took 3+ months. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA) in July 2011.
Interview Description: Terrible process. Although they were nice enough to accommodate some of my scheduling issues, it was handled awfully. For example, after two phone screen interviews in mid-April that they were flying me out for an onsite interview, but due to significant screw-ups on their part (and a 3 week period when I was on vacation), it didn't happen till mid-July.The interview scheduling itself was quite awful. Thrice, they asked me for dates that I could fly to California. Twice, those dates went by without any contact from them (even though I told them I had another offer, and they assured me they would hurry up). The third time, they emailed me the morning before and said I was going to be booked on a flight the next day! And then after I reminded them at 9 PM that night that I still didn't have tickets for my flight the next morning, they sent them to me about half an hour before midnight. I blame this, in part, for not having enough time to prepare.The interview itself was OK, although I don't think I did well enough to get an offer. One interviewer was openly hostile towards me because he saw my major on my resume and immediately assumed that I was not qualified (He actually said the words "Your major is XXX. Why have you even applied for THIS job?"). They assured me a result very quickly, within a day or two, since I had to tell the other company that made me an offer to wait. It's been 3 days now, and no reply. I've pretty much given up hope; even if they do make me an offer, I'm not sure I want to work here
Interview Questions: Question about HTTP requests, AJAX and algorithms   1 Answer

Application: I applied through other source. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA) in July 2011.
Interview Description: - Recruiter screening (Week 1)- Phone interview screen by hiring manager (Week 2)- Phone interview screen by Senior Engineer - Technical Round (Week 3)- In person interview with 10 people (Week 4)- Salary and package negotiation (Week 5)Signed NDA. Can't talk about the questions and other details
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work for VMWare ?   Answer Question

Application: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at VMware (Cambridge, MA) in June 2011.
Interview Description: 2 rounds of telephonic1 round onlineOnsite 1:1
Interview Questions: Programming ConceptsQuestions pertaining to resume   Answer Question

Application: The process took 4+ weeks. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA) in March 2012.
Interview Description: Overall I had 5 phone interviews that took about 6 hours and 5 one-on-one and group interviews On site that took about 5 hoursI was contacted by a recruiter after about a month after submitting an application online. The recruiter was extremely nice and incredibly helpful. The inital recruiter screening went well and I was told it would be progressing.I was contacted a couple of days later by one of the senior guys on the team. It was a fun discussion about goals, ambitions, history, experience and expectations. The call lasted about an hour.I then had a further thee phone interviews over the coming week, including a pair programming technical test with an highly skilled engineer from outside the team.I really enjoyed the banter and the attitude from everyone, it was exactly the right mix of knowledge, skill work ethic and fun.The onsite interviews were excellent fun, I met with all the senior players, including my bosses, bosses, boss. There was a lot of white board drawing, solutions questions & scalability questions. Everyone was extremely nice and engaging, I actually enjoyed myself and never once felt out of place or out of my league. The interviews were typically 45m to an hour each, some were group chats, others were 1:1I left feeling excited and highly motivated. It was a very pleasant experience.I liked everyone I met.
Interview Questions: What bottleneck challenges do you think we would face is this architecture was scaled up x50,000   Answer Question

Application: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA) in March 2012.
Interview Description: Find the convergence point of 2 linked list
Interview Questions: Find the convergence point of 2 linked list   2 Answers

Application: I applied online. The process took 2+ weeks. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA) in August 2012.
Interview Description: One round of phone screen and a onsite interview. Talk with four engineers and one managers during on-site visit. Many technical questions with code writing on whiteboard
Interview Questions: Find a minimal editing distance between two strings   1 Answer

Application: I applied online. The process took 4+ weeks. I interviewed at VMware in February 2008.
Interview Description: Phone screen.Onsite interview - I felt onsite interview very un-organized. They kept changing conference room. I was roaming around in the middle of the day because they could not find a interviewer. HR came in the middle of the day to plug the whole, could not fill it full thought.
Interview Questions: NAN

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA) in August 2012.
Interview Description: I was contacted by a recruiter. After exchanging a few emails, he arranged a phone interview. The phone interview last about an hour.
Interview Questions: The questions were like:- why vmware- what is difference between process and thread- how to you debug a server process which crashes randomly   Answer Question

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 4+ weeks. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA).
Interview Description: Starts with a phone screen with hr and they give you a choice of tea prom to join. Later there is a technical phone screen with a team member. The office interview has 5 to 6 people. Some development, management, and hr. Sometimes interviews are two days. There are logic and programing questions.
Interview Questions: One person asked me use of const in C++   1 Answer

Application: I applied through college or university. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at VMware (Atlanta, GA) in March 2015.
Interview Description: Applied through recruiter at my universities' career fair. Had one phone interview and one onsite interview in Atlanta. Everyone was very nice. The questions at the onsite interview were mainly OOP questions.
Interview Questions: count the number of 1s in the binary of a number.   Answer Question

Application: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at VMware in January 2014.
Interview Description: Long and comprehensive interview. For a recent graduate from college, prepare to dig deep in your theoretical knowledge on computing, engineering, algorithms, software languages (both script and compile). They hire the best, and they want to make sure you qualify and can keep up with the rest.
Interview Questions: I was given several "find best algorithm" of a given scenario. In this case, it was to create a random number generator of seven numbers recursively buy only using a random number generator of 5 numbers.   Answer Question

Application: I interviewed at VMware in November 2014.
Interview Description: Campus Recuitment via career fair. The HR lady is very friendly. Next day one on one 45 mins interview with one of technical recuiters at campus. After you clear this round, then they call you on sight depending on the slot allocated for your university. First they show you the campus around for 1 hour and then 2 back to back technical interviews for 45 mins each.
Interview Questions: Nothing in particular but need to practise general coding ques. Both C and Java based.   Answer Question

Application: I applied online. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at VMware in September 2015.
Interview Description: Sent my resume online and got a online challenge link in s few days. The online challenge take about 200 minutes and contains 5 questions, which are all coding problems. The questions are long and time-consuming. I think the company is testing if you truly want to apply for the job.
Interview Questions: Assume A is a number smaller than B. Find the nth number created with combination of A and B (such as AABB, ABAB, ABBA). The number of A will be equal to the number of B.   Answer Question

Application: I applied through college or university. The process took a week. I interviewed at VMware (Champaign, IL) in September 2015.
Interview Description: The interview took place at my university. There were two 45 minute back to back interviews. The interviewers were very respectful and helpful. My first interviewer asked technical questions and my second interviewer ask more behavioral questions although not a lot. Most of the technical questions were related to data structures except there was one about systems. My second interviewer spent time telling me about what the company does, what products they offer, etc. and I thought it was really interesting. Unfortunately, I did not get an offer, but I will try again next semester.
Interview Questions: Questions about arrays, linked lists, BSTs, etc.   1 Answer

Application: The process took 3+ months. I interviewed at VMware.
Interview Description: Online coding challenge round is compulsory. Unfortunately I was asked to write programs in java where as I am only comfortable with c and python. But recruiter was really a nice guy. He was very quick in responding to emails and any queries.
Interview Questions: search a element in a cyclic sorted array .   1 Answer

Application: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA).
Interview Description: It was a phone interview in which there was a discussion of several computer networking concepts and a coding question. The coding question was to write a function to traverse the nodes of a tree in breadth first manner. This was followed by an onsite interview in which I talked to six people
Interview Questions: How to obtain the sum of the elements from (0,0) to (r,c) in a 2D array, where r and c are the row and column numbers   4 Answers

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 4+ weeks. I interviewed at VMware (Austin, TX) in February 2016.
Interview Description: The interview took about a month. I interviewed at VMware in Austin. I was first contacted by a recruiter, was sent to a HackerRank challenge, and had an onsite interview. After passing the onsite interview I had another HackerRank challenge with a senior director over the phone.
Interview Questions: The first HackerRank challenge I had was an abstract design problem where I was told, within 90 minutes, to write a function that detects whether a robot loops within a trajectory passed as an arbitrary commands string that controls the movement of the robot. (e.g. GRGRGL where L stands for turn left, R for turn right and G for go one step)   1 Answer

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware (Austin, TX) in February 2016.
Interview Description: I had an on-campus interview with VMware after meeting them at UT's EXPO (engineering career fair). I came in fairly formal business wear, but found that it was unnecessary because everyone there had been dressed casually. I had a one-on-one interview for 30-45 minutes, and then an interview with two of VMware's software engineers for another 30-45 minutes.
Interview Questions: My interviewer was aware that I didn't have much experience, so it felt as though he was going easy on me/wasn't expecting as much. There was a heavy emphasis on C and he had me look at two pieces of code to catch a race condition. The two interviewers after gave me the option to work in C or java, so I chose java. They were simple questions about manipulating data.   1 Answer

Application: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at VMware.

Application: I applied online. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA) in December 2015.
Interview Description: Standard screening and onsite interviews. Recruiting team was very helpful during the process.Onsite interviewers were knowledge and the interviews were pleasant. The interviews also gave me a good idea about the role.

Application: NAN

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took a week. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA) in October 2016.

Application: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA) in June 2015.
Interview Description: It was an individual with the hiring manager and then a panel with 5 employees then with HR. I had already spoken to the hiring manager over the phone so meeting in person was more of a meet and greet. A little bit nervous for a meet and greet but the hiring manager was very affirming that my experience met their requirements quite well. We sat for about 15 minutes and the Hiring manager spoke more in-depth about the team/about VMWare in terms of culture fit. After exchanging pleasantries, he invited the rest of the team to meet. It was a panel which made the interview a bit more nerve racking. Each person asked a question and it seemed over 15 questions, some of the questions were similar...as if the interviewers were more involved in the questions they were going to as rather than listen to other interviewers and ask different questions. The panel lasted for 60 minutes. The clue that everything went well was that HR came in and had a chat. They asked the straight forward question of when can you start. If you get one of those type questions, you can now relax, dry off the sweat and take a sip of water.
Interview Questions: Started with technical questions with a very thorough drill down of my resume and how it is very similar to the achievements the team is trying to complete.   1 Answer

Then I got an onsite interview. There were four rounds, and one of them is about system design. The other rounds consist of CS fundamentals, projects in resume and coding problems. Application: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware (Austin, TX) in June 2016.
Interview Description: All day, multiple phases, but felt like it could end abruptly after each phase. Talked with an assortment of managers, and also a couple of senior engineers. I sat for 3 morning interviews, was taken to lunch (not sure if this is normal), and then sat for 3 afternoon interviews. Each interview was different. One person gave me a written programming test, another did a thought experiment, another asked me to whiteboard the solution to a programming challenge, another asked me to diagram the internals of an application framework.
Interview Questions: I was asked to describe the internal mechanism involved in the Ruby implementation of enumerables. This seemed to be an off-the-cuff question, flowing from a discussion of various languages, and their strengths and weaknesses.   Answer Question

Application: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at VMware.
Interview Description: On campus interview, took less than an hour. technique questions are very easy. but be well prepared to answer questions on your resume. Interview question mostly focus on data structure.
Interview Questions: Reverse Singly Linked ListDetecting a Loop in Singly Linked ListLinkedHashmap   1 Answer

Application: I applied through college or university. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at VMware in October 2016.
Interview Description: Taken an online assessment, and then had an on-campus interview with two software engineers of the company. Was provided with both object-oriented programming questions and also given some questions in regards to solving a real world problem.
Interview Questions: Implement a data structure that keeps track of 50 integers. How would you build this data structure to check if an element is present, and if the structure is full, remove the oldest element? There are also no duplicates.   1 Answer

Application: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware (San Jose, CA) in October 2016.
Interview Description: Four people interview(1 to 1, each people will cost 45 min), please feel easy, they are very nice.If you do not have some difficulty, you could communicate with interviewer in time. They will give some tips.
Interview Questions: Some behavior question and some algorithm question   Answer Question

Application: I applied through college or university. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at VMware (New York, NY).
Interview Description: I interview at Airwatch, Atlanta. The on-campus interview was algorithmic questions with no coding at all. The onsite interview involved one group interview and one individual interview. The interviewer didn't pay attention to me at all when I answer the question. The question was pretty straigth-forward and easy.
Interview Questions: How to design a sync system like Dropbox?   Answer Question

Application: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4+ weeks. I interviewed at VMware in December 2016.
Interview Description: Initial phone screening followed by two hour long technical interviews. Initial screening was helpful because they asked me what my interests were. Technical interviews were medium difficulty, covered topics in data structures and testing.
Interview Questions: Understanding of data structures, testing to see if I understood where to use certain structures.   1 Answer

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA) in February 2017.
Interview Description: this is the simplest interview I ever been too....but the real problem is not the interview but the HR's.I interviewed twice in a month with different teams (NSBU and NSX) in Vmware, dammm simple interviews...but after the interview HR told me that they will revert back to me within a week, one HR even said after the interview that the team really like you and they want you onboard...but after that they never contacted me, I had tried sending them reminder email but no reply....VMware have horrible HR's....I would not recommend this company to anyone.....I don't care how busy there life is but its basic courtesy to reply...I hope vmware teach them basic "Human Resource" management, since they lack it horribly
Interview Questions: add 1 + number given in linked listlca of bst   1 Answer

Application: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at VMware in June 2014.
Interview Description: Pretty hard. I did phone interview first with some basic questions about Objective-c and Xcode unit testing. Then went to onsite with 1:1. Total with 2 persons.Asked many questions from UI related to basic algorithms.
Interview Questions: Asked about autolayout   Answer Question

Application: I applied through a recruiter. I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA) in November 2017.
Interview Description: It was the Propel program, which is designed for new graduate students. I got a hackerrank test after contacting a recruiter. The hackerrank test was not hard. Then I got an onsite invitation. On the onsite day, there was a tour of their campus. There were four whiteboard coding rounds of onsite interview. The first round was about binary tree serialization and deserialization, but there was some extra requirements. The second and the third rounds were about linked lists. These three rounds of algorithm and data structures were not hard. Unfortunately, the fourth round was bunch of questions about operating systems and networks. These questions were really difficult and full of details.
Interview Questions: How sliding window in TCP can increase the network efficiency?   Answer Question

Application: I interviewed at VMware (Palo Alto, CA) in January 2018.
Interview Description: Recruiter contacted on LinkedIn asking for my resume. He sent HackerRank coding challenge telling I have to finish it by end of next day. Coding challenge had 4 questions with 60min. And each question were page long to read, which in itself would take 10+min to read and understand each question and they weren't simple enough to be completed in 5min. Will be evaluated on number of passed answers and not on your code/approach/thought process, so don't try to solve all questions with partial answers but make sure to submit at least 3 questions with no errors. I submitted with 2 perfect answers and 2 partial and was rejected in an hour.
Interview Questions: Basic data structure like Strings, array, tree   Answer Question

Application: I applied online. I interviewed at VMware.
Interview Description: There will be initial screening from Recruiter. Recruiter will get as much details about your background, work, expectations etc. Based on fitment to the job a person will get a link to HackerRank test. Once HackerRank test is completed you will be called for onsite interview.
Interview Questions: Hacker Rank Coding test followed by Onsite Interview   2 Answers

Application: I applied online. I interviewed at VMware.
Interview Description: Phone Interview with a shared screen of coding complier. First ask 3 generic questions about the front-end web framework, the one coding question. I believe, the all questions grading rubric are just pass or no pass.
Interview Questions: Write a javascript class that subscript msg from server and print it, or send msg to the server.   Answer Question

Application: I applied through other source. The process took 2+ months. I interviewed at VMware (Atlanta, GA) in October 2015.
Interview Description: The hiring process was somewhat disorganized, as the recruiters often sent emails to the candidates and spelled their first and last names incorrectly. Among the three technical interviewers, two acted rude and unprofessional, which killed my desire, on the spot, to ever intern at this company.
Interview Questions: Describe and write out a fast C implementation of a least-recently-used (LRU) cache.   1 Answer

Application: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at VMware (Chicago, IL) in March 2015.
Interview Description: Phone interview, was very difficult to talk to, interviewer did not seem to want to be there. I tried to write code but the interviewer kept being difficult about some of the questions I asked. e.g. I would try to clarify an edge case and he would say "what do you think?"
Interview Questions: Multiple inheritance, Java, object-oriented stuff.   Answer Question

Application: I applied through college or university. The process took a week. I interviewed at VMware (Urbana, IL) in September 2016.
Interview Description: I talked to recruiter at career fair. On campus interview a week after that. I was the last candidate of the day. The interview supposed to be 30 minutes long, but it got to an hour long. Interviewer had a pretty heavy accent, so sometimes I had to ask him to repeat his questions.
Interview Questions: Bunch of networking and web questions.Move all 0's to the end of the list   1 Answer

Application: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at VMware (Los Angeles, CA) in October 2017.
Interview Description: The interview was for networking graduates, 2 rounds of interview1st Round of interview: Basic questions about process, threads, virtual memory concepts and networking concepts and a Hacker Rank coding problem2nd Round Interview: Networking concepts, operating system and a Hacker rank coding problem.Interview process was good and the whole process went over for a month
Interview Questions: Difference between process and threads   1 Answer

Application: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at VMware.
Interview Description: The interviewer was very dull and not nice, and he kept asking me questions about ASP.NET while I told him that I don't have experience in ASP.NET and the job description didn't ask for it either. You would expect a company this big would be to the point.
Interview Questions: Gibberish about ASP.NET   Answer Question

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware (Bengaluru (India)) in June 2014.
Interview Description: It was a 3 step process -1) A written round - (Analytical and Technical questions)2) F2F interview - Technical and puzzle round.3) HR round - Its more of a formality than a round.First Round -Analytical Questions - The questions were from easy to average level. It tested concepts of angles, averages, AP GP , Time and Distance and other basic class 10 maths.Technical Questions - I was given an option to choose my Technical Paper ( C++/Java/Android).The questions were from easy to difficult but you don't actually need to answer all correctly. There is no negative marking and all questions carry equal weightage. So if you are able to do 70% of it you should be through.
Interview Questions: This is about India Airwatch office.In HR round, I was asked some personal questions like1. How many sibling you have?2. Are you married?3. What's your parent's occupation?4. How many kids do you have?These are personal question and need not to be asked and answered. Till date I have given 10 interview but no where these were asked. I do not know what was on their mind while asking these questions. If they wanted to show that they are very friendly then my answer is you guys don't know what HR needs to ask in interview. They need some training to handle their job properly.   Answer Question

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at VMware in September 2014.
Interview Description: I was contacted on Linked in by recruiter. The communication was pleasant and informative. I was asked to complete a timed (one hour) coding question online at my convenience. If the coding question went well, then I would be invited to participate at the interview event. I completed the coding question, and submitted my solution.
Interview Questions: 1) Flip the Bits : What is the maximum number if 1 - bits (indicated by S) which you can obtain in the final bit string? 'Flipping ' a bit means , that a 0 is transformed to a 1 and a 1 is transformed to a 0. String is some like "1001011".2) Transverse the multi dimensional matrix: Find the number of paths to the bottom - right of the cell   3 Answers

Application: I applied online. I interviewed at VMware (Bengaluru (India)) in September 2014.
Interview Description: First Round(At AirWatch office):10 coding questions + 5 Aptitude questions to write on paper(you heard it right, 10 questions on paper).Your hands would start paining, by the end of it.The questions were same as given by others in the interview review.I wrote all 10 coding questions as well as aptitude ones.Second Round(At AirWatch office)(Not a technical round per-se):Just after submitting paper pen solutions I had a round scheduled with the head of Bangalore div.It was more of a discussion on my current project, my solutions of paper pen round and my general horizon of technical expertise.I was clearly told:"We wont keep you in dark, Mon. HR will schedule a telephonic technical round for you".I was repeatedly told"We wont keep you in dark".Alas! Its still dark! No communication, no reply to mails, phone calls.I just didn't understand, All 10 coding questions wrote properly(they were same questions as stated in glassdoor), Second round went well(It wasn't even Technical!!).
Interview Questions: None, Written round was same as given on GlassDoor and there was no technical round.   Answer Question

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 4+ weeks. I interviewed at VMware.
Interview Description: They contacted me for a recruiting event that was taking place in Bucharest. After an online coding problem, I was selected to attend the event. They were looking for candidates for the office in Sofia. At each interview, there were 2 engineers asking questions. One of them was asking questions and the other one was taking notes on his personal notebook. (There were cases when the other person also asked questions)The first interview was the most unpleasant one; the interviewer was very mild and seemed a little bit nervous. I didn't like the interview at all because it was very Java oriented with questions that you either know, or you don't. As an example, he asked me which was the use of the volatile keyword in Java.The second interview was better, because the questions were put in such a way that they wanted to see how you think and approach a problem. They asked me to write code and implement a method that counts the number of vowels from a given string. They asked about the complexity, about how can we improve it and things like that, on the code that I've written. The discussion went quite well.The third interview was only with one QA engineer. He asked the basics of algorithms (queue, stack, hashing, sorting). After that he asked a design question: I had to write code for a Square and a Rectangle. The last part of the interview was focused on testing: he showed me an API and asked me how would I test it.After that, a guy that recommended himself as being from the VMWare offices in Palo Alto came in and told me that I am exactly the guy that they are looking for, but they can't make me an offer for now; I have to progress on the technical side.Overall it was a nice experience; there were moments (for example at the second interview) when I was so absorbed by the discussion that I even forgot that I am at an interview. It was quite cool.
Interview Questions: One of the most strange/unexpected/difficult questions was the following one: considering 2 methods that do exactly the same thing; one of them is public, and the other one is private. The call to which of those methods will be executed faster, and motivate why?   1 Answer

Application: NAN
Interview Description: Interview process was good
Interview Questions: Weird questions to test your response   Answer Question

Application: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at VMware.
Interview Description: The process starts with the written test in the campus.The paper consists of simple aptitude c,c++ ,data structure ,os,DBMS networking questions.
Interview Questions: During the interview,the interviewer asked about segment tree.   Answer Question

Application: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware in February 2010.
Interview Description: Had two round of phone screens. Then was brought onsite. Met 6 people in total. Questions cover data structure, algorithms, behavior, brain teaser, distributed systems, database, design pattern, networks, and etc.1. Given a two dimensional array of characters, provide an implementationwhich would print out the characters in the array in a spiral manner.2. Write a regular expression pattern to match "525", "528", and "530" to"599" exclusively.
Interview Questions: Given a two dimensional array of characters, provide an implementationwhich would print out the characters in the array in a spiral manner.   2 Answers

Application: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware in February 2009.
Interview Description: This is a tough interview. From the very beginning the recruiter asked me to explain the algorithm of various sorting methods, and comparing their advantages and disadvantages. Afterwards, He gave me a program clip, and asked me to find as many bugs as possible. That was really tough, because you have the pressure of interview, and you cannot think of what is wrong. I did bad, and did not get the offer.
Interview Questions: What is your most successful project you have ever did?   Answer Question

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware in February 2011.
Interview Description: These guys are very very specific. Don't surprise if interviewer ask question like "What is the name of dll that has ... blah blah fxn ....".Conclusion: They are not going to test your smartness but will test your memory.1. Bad for folks who like challanges2. Good for guys who are ok with repeated work and confined knowledge.
Interview Questions: What is name of dll that contains File function ....   Answer Question

Application: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2+ months. I interviewed at VMware in June 2011.
Interview Description: I had quite a nightmare dealing with this company. Their HR seems very incompetent.I was initially put in contact with their HR in Ireland. They were very nice and professional. Then, after speaking with a couple of folks there, I was routed to their HR in California. I was scheduled for an interview in which the interviewer felt more like chatting than interviewing. He said that I could ask him whatever I wanted. So, we had a casual conversation (about VMware and what it is like to work there) for 30 minutes after which he indicated that the next round of phone interviews would be more technical and that I should get ready for this.Now, it's been nearly two months since I had my first interview and requests to HR to get back to me have fallen on deaf ears. At this point, I'm sure that I don't want to work for this company even if they do move the process forward. If they treat you like this before you join, what happens afterward?
Interview Questions: What questions do you have for me?   1 Answer

Application: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware in September 2011.
Interview Description: Got the on-campus interview and have a nice experience with the tech recruiter. He walked through my project experiences and asked about my vision for career path, etc. Common questions and positive feedbacks.
Interview Questions: Describe what you would like to become in five years.   Answer Question

Application: The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware in January 2012.
Interview Description: I was referred by one of my friend in this group.The manger seems interested in what I have done in my phd study.After briefly discussed with him about my projects, he started to askme general technical questions. I have answered some of them includinghow to implement a semaphore, spinlock, read write lock, interrupt, etc.I guess I was rejected.
Interview Questions: How to implement a semaphore using mutex and conditional value by pthread?   Answer Question

Application: The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at VMware in January 2012.
Interview Description: HR contacted me and gave a homework to solve (coding, three problems). Another e-mail after a couple of days later was sent to me to set up a phone interview. The problem was "converting from string to integer". It went well. A couple of days later, another e-mail and set up the second interview (linked list problem). I solved the problem, but I received the e-mail saying not best match.
Interview Questions: Return number list in the string   1 Answer

Application: The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at VMware in August 2011.
Interview Description: it is phone interview
Interview Questions: Describe locking mechanism required for network drivers in multi processor system.   Answer Question

Application: The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware in February 2012.
Interview Description: Received a call from a recruiter person at VMWare. He sent me an email with a list of 3 questions asking to solve any 1.
Interview Questions: NAN

Application: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at VMware in May 2012.
Interview Description: Standard process, no surprise.
Interview Questions: Behavioral questions to assess fit with company culture.   Answer Question

Application: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at VMware in May 2012.
Interview Description: Couple of technical Phone interviews
Interview Questions: Describe about the projects i worked on   Answer Question

Application: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at VMware.
Interview Description: the first round was a written test. There had asked few programming questions and a few analytical questions. The analytical questions were quite simple. The programming questions were ok but a little time taking.
Interview Questions: Asked me about my college projects   1 Answer

Application: The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware (Bengaluru (India)) in March 2015.
Interview Description: The worst experience- The company standards don't look like VMware type. Very disappointing behavior.First round - Written Test - 5 Coding questions, you have to pen down the answers completely.Second Round - A technical interview with easy going questions such as basic OOPS concept, SQL queries and basic program on strings.Director Round- Again a technical discussion on design patterns and questions on javascript.HR Round - basic soft skills and package discussion.After clearing all these rounds, you cant expect an offer letter from them. Yes, you have read correct that they won't send you offer letter in any case if you have answered all questions properly, even director told you that you have cleared all rounds. Even director is not sure about his decision.It is the worst experience I would call. If you are completely free then only go for the interview otherwise it is waste of time.
Interview Questions: Find the pair of number which has the given sum?   Answer Question

Application: NAN
Interview Description: ask some question about system debug and profiling, just do some coding for stack and a tree browser logic. Not very hard, take easy and get the position. the interviewer is quite nice and do not take a long time. This company choose people carefully.
Interview Questions: tree browser is a difficult question   Answer Question

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at VMware (Yerevan (Armenia)) in October 2013.
Interview Description: The technical interviews were not difficult and up to the point. On the first interview I was asked some general questions to check my understanding of software engineering, experience etc. The second day I was required to write some code in an online text editor. Usually I get a little nervous in situations like that, but the interviewer was a really nice person, and I felt comfortable writing the test.
Interview Questions: To code an algorithm in an online editor.   Answer Question

Application: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at VMware (Bengaluru (India)) in November 2015.
Interview Description: nice good people good hr basic questions where asked and some output were asked overall it is easy what is thread what is seamphore like so many question were asked
Interview Questions: similar   Answer Question

Application: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at VMware (Bengaluru (India)) in August 2015.
Interview Description: VMware came to my college to hire software engineer, at the end of day they told me they will keep me under consideration.Next week I was contacted by them thrice and teach time they told me manager wants to talk to me but they never contacted me after, didn't reply for my mails though I followed up several times, NO REPLY at all. Very disappointing and unprofessional.
Interview Questions: Interview question were simple basic linklist question,Java,algorithms   Answer Question

Application: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at VMware (Indi, Karnataka (India)) in October 2015.
Interview Description: Initial rounds were Multiple Choice Questions based on aptitude and core subjects like C, algorithms, networking held at campus . Later had 3-4 rounds of technical and personal interviews, for which they called the selected candidates to their office.
Interview Questions: Mot of the questions asked related to java and networking   Answer Question

Application: I applied online. I interviewed at VMware (Sofia (Bulgaria)) in June 2017.
Interview Description: First you have to answer a few questions over the phone then they email you with a quiz that should be done in an hour. The quiz has 5 question with choosing an answer and 2 tasks.
Interview Questions: Transforming digits from decimal to binary make some manipulation and return them back in binary.   Answer Question

Application: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware (Manipal (India)) in September 2017.
Interview Description: Online Test had some aptitude questions and really good operating systems , DBMS and other CS concepts. Further rounds tested coding skills in data structure implementations, bit manipulation and how efficiently all the errors were handled and how the time complexity was optimized.
Interview Questions: Implement using any data structure , a system to store all the employee records.Also ensure that it is dynamically increasing. Make the search and insertion efficient.   Answer Question

Application: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at VMware.
Interview Description: questions regarding projects were asked and also about the family background and stuff. Interviewers were kind enough. First round was aptitude, second was group discussion and later 2 rounds of technical followed by hr interview.
Interview Questions: To explain where I came from. Changes experienced in the current and previous places.   Answer Question

Application: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at VMware (Nagpur, Maharashtra (India)) in August 2017.
Interview Description: I sat in the VMware recruitment process through the on-campus drive. First was aptitude round which contains distinct sections. The 1st section had 10 questions of quantitative aptitude, there were 3 more sections containing OS, CN, DAA and code related questions in any 2 of the 3 languages(Java, C++, Python). There was a coding section too in which you had properly code and run your logic for a program in 30 minutes. Then there were 4 interview rounds: 2 Technical, Manager and HR round. The interviewers were friendly and did all they could to calm the candidate.From an interview perspective, students can focus on the following points:1. Programming ability: Should be able to write algorithms and convert it into "bug-free" code which implements what is asked.2. Data Structures: Strong hold on Linked Lists, Trees, and Graphs. (more the merrier)3. Operating Systems: the syllabus is sufficient for this. Should compulsorily focus on multi threading and concurrency.4. Basic knowledge of the company and products. Should have good knowledge about virtualization and cloud.5. Knowledge of other technologies will certainly help.6. No specific programming language requirements as such, but should be proficient in either of C/C++, Java or Python
Interview Questions: Everything under the sun covered in IT/CSE syllabus. Especially OOP concepts. Also was asked to explain the logic of the programming question that came in aptitude.   Answer Question

Application: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware (Bengaluru (India)) in December 2014.
Interview Description: Hiring Process has three stages.1. Written Test which includes 7-10 programming questions and 5-6 analytical questions.2. Two or more rounds of technical interview which has few algorithmic questions and rest of discussion about past projects3. HR interview
Interview Questions: 1. Describe your recent project.2. Behavioral questions3. Few questions about design patterns   Answer Question

Application: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware (Sofia (Bulgaria)) in January 2017.
Interview Description: The interview process took nearly the whole day. I was supposed to meet 4 interviewers in particular order, but they couldn't manage to follow the order.I was given a pc with eclipse IDE to write some program for a fixed amount of time. The complexity wasn't huge, but the time wasn't really enough to produce a full scale solution.Then couple of guys started asking me questions trying as hard as possible to find what I didn't know ... of course there would be things I don't know ... I'm not a book after all...The guys came up with a WRONG concept too, but they were the examiners, so I couldn't really argue with them pointing out that their opinion was wrong.The team manager had some ideas about managing people and organizing work, but I wouldn't say he was the best of class..And then the HR department wasted another hour of my time to talk gibberish...
Interview Questions: Design patterns - tell us what you know...   Answer Question

Application: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at VMware (Yerevan (Armenia)).
Interview Description: They gave 3 different problems (apparently same ones to many of the applicants)...Problems are all very interesting and practical, rather easy for entry.Most importantly you dont do this on a blackboard, you get time to implement and send solutions as an attachment. However i strongly recommend you to solve them yourself dont google the solutions or if you do make sure you completely ready to answer any questions about them at the actual on site interview...
Interview Questions: Compute median from stream of integers...   1 Answer

Application: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at VMware (Herzliya (Israel)) in January 2015.
Interview Description: The interview was in a group of 6-7 people, however the applicants were not supposed to interact. Every applicant got a computer with internet, a prepared Google account and an Eclipse-like environment. The task was to write a client which searches Youtube by a keyword and represents the search results as a list of videos. It was allowed to use any code found in the Internet.The time allowed to complete the task was 2 and a half hours. The overall time was 3 hours. Every participant was called to a personal interview of half an hour with 2 interviewers.
Interview Questions: The question was asked in the personal interview.You are climbing a stair case. It takes n steps to reach to the top. Each time you can either climb 1 or 2 steps. Write a program which computes in how many distinct ways can you climb to the top.   5 Answers

Application: I applied in-person. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at VMware (Ben (India)).
Interview Description: One word. PATHETIC.In all the interview rounds, interviewers were too much engaged in their phones. They didn’t much pay attention towards the answers, I was giving. In one of the rounds, I literally had to stop explaining my solution as interviewer was not at all listening(Later I came to know that he was the manager). In one of the rounds, interviewer was so confused that he didn’t even know what he wanted to ask. He changed the question at least 5 times.They do not have any courtesy towards the candidates.On rejection, when I asked HR about the feedback, he said that he has received feedback in only 2 lines that they have mixed reviews and hence they are not proceeding with my candidacy.
Interview Questions: Merging point in 2 linked lists.   Answer Question
